current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To aid and support pediatric involvement in reading and
		  education.

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Health, Education, Labor,
			 and Pensions

cosponsor.#tail:
)
			 introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is amended by adding
			 at the end the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Part D of title V of the Elementary and
			 Secondary Education Act of 1965
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/t:V/pt:D

header.#text:
Pediatric
			 involvement in reading and education

text.#text: In this subpart:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, demonstrated
				effectiveness in the following areas:

term.#tail:
means a nonprofit
				organization that has, as determined by the

text.#text: The term

Providing
				peer-to-peer training to healthcare providers in research-based methods of
				literacy promotion as part of routine pediatric health supervision
				visits.

Delivering a
				training curriculum through a variety of medical education settings, including
				residency training, continuing medical education, and national pediatric
				conferences.

Providing
				technical assistance to local healthcare facilities to effectively implement a
				high-quality Pediatric Early Literacy Program.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:5626

text.#text:
Offering
				opportunities for local healthcare facilities to obtain books at significant
				discounts, as described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:5621/p:1/sp:B

text.#text:
Integrating the
				latest developmental and educational research into the training curriculum for
				healthcare providers described in
The term

creates and
				implements a 3-part model through which—

healthcare
				providers, doctors, and nurses, trained in research-based methods of early
				language and literacy promotion, encourage parents to read aloud to their young
				children, and offer developmentally appropriate recommendations and strategies
				to parents for the purpose of reading aloud to their children;

healthcare
				providers, at health supervision visits, provide each child between the ages of
				6 months and 5 years a new, developmentally appropriate children’s book to take
				home and keep; and

demonstrates,
				through research published in peer-reviewed journals, effectiveness in
				positively altering parent behavior regarding reading aloud to children, and
				improving expressive and receptive language in young children; and

receives the
				endorsement of nationally recognized medical associations and academies.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is
				authorized to award grants to eligible entities to enable the eligible entities
				to implement Pediatric Early Literacy Programs.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall submit an application to the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:5622

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
at such
				time, in such manner, and including such information as the

may
				reasonably require.

text.#text:
An eligible entity that desires to receive a
				grant under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall provide, either directly or through
				private contributions, non-Federal matching funds equal to not less than 50
				percent of the grant received by the eligible entity under
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:5622

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
. Such
				matching funds may be in cash or in-kind.

, under which each contractor will agree to
				establish and operate a Pediatric Early Literacy Program;

enter into contracts with private nonprofit

provide such

text.#text:
include such

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
on the basis of the extent to which the contractor gives priority to

text.#text: Each contractor shall be selected under

children from
				families with an income below 200 percent of the poverty line applicable to a
				family of the size involved, particularly such children in high-poverty
				areas;

children without
				adequate medical insurance;

children enrolled
				in a State Medicaid program, established under

or in the State Children's Health Insurance

children living

migrant children;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall make no payment to an eligible entity under this subpart unless the

determines that the eligible entity or a contractor of the eligible
				entity, as the case may be, has made arrangements with book publishers or
				distributors to obtain books at discounts that are at least as favorable as
				discounts that are customarily given by such publisher or distributor for book
				purchases made under similar circumstances in the absence of Federal
				assistance.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall report annually to the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:5622

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
on
				the effectiveness of the program implemented by the eligible entity and the
				programs instituted by each contractor of the eligible entity, and shall
				include in the report a description of each
				program.
